Text.p: Understanding position functions allows us to model real-world motion. By representing position as a function of time, mathematics provides a way to predict and analyze movement. Tables, graphs, and formulas work together to tell the complete story of an object’s motion over time.

In this lesson, the height of a ball thrown straight upward is described by the function s(t)=-16t^2+v_0t+h_0, where time t, initial velocity v_0, and starting height h_0 determine the ball’s position at any given moment. This approach forms the foundation for countless applications in science, engineering, and technology.

choice.explanation: The table shows that the ball’s height s(t) equals 0 at t = 0 and at t = 8 \text{,} but not at t = 1 \text{.}
The table shows that at t = 1 \text{,} the ball’s height s(t) is 112 \text{ ft} \text{.}
The table shows that s(t) = 256 is the height of the ball at t = 4 \text{,} not at t = 1 \text{.}

choice.label: the ball’s horizontal motion
choice.explanation: A common misconception is that the graph shows the ball moving horizontally. However, the ball has no horizontal motion. The ball only goes up and down.

choice.label: the ball’s height
choice.explanation: The vertical axis, not the horizontal axis, represents the ball’s height.

choice.label: time
choice.explanation: The horizontal axis represents time, while the vertical axis represents the ball’s height. The function s(t) relates time t (input) and the ball’s height s (output).

ShortAnswer.question: The ball’s height at t = 6 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

Hints.hint: Substitute t = 6 into s(t) = -16t^2 + 128t\text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The ball’s height is calculated by substituting 6 for t into the function s(t) \text{.}

TextResource.Text: The height of a ball thrown into the air is modeled by s(t) = -16t^2 + 48t \text{,} where s is given in feet and t is given in seconds. Downward-opening parabola <m>y = f(x)</m> on labeled <m>x</m>-<m>y</m> axes, maximum at <m>(1.

MultipleChoice.question: The ball is going up until t= \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} seconds, after which the ball goes down.

choice.explanation: The graph is increasing on the interval [0,1.5] \text{,} so the ball is going up during this time. The graph is decreasing on the interval [1.5,3] \text{,} so the ball is going down during this time.
36 is a height, not a time. Instead, consider the t\text{-coordinate.}
The ball is not going up during the entire time from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds. Instead, find when the graph changes from increasing to decreasing.

MultipleChoice.question: What is true about the height of the ball at t=1 and t = 2 seconds? The ball is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.label: at the same height at t=1 and t = 2 seconds
choice.explanation: The heights of the graph at t=1 and t=2 are identical. The algebraic representation also shows that the heights are identical: \begin{align*} h(t) &= -16t^2 + 48t \\ h(1) &= -16(1)^2 + 48(1)\\ &= -16 + 48 \\ &= 32 \text{ feet}\\ h(2) &= -16(2)^2 + 48(2) \\ &= -64 + 96\\ &= 32 \text{ feet}\\ \end{align*}

choice.label: higher at t = 1 second than at t = 2 seconds
higher at t = 2 seconds than at t = 1 second

ShortAnswer.question: The height of the ball at t = 0.5 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

Hints.hint: The height of the ball at t = 0.5 seconds is h(0.5) \text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: The height of the ball will be the same at t=0.5 and t = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

Hints.hint: The ball reaches a height of 20 \text{ feet} at t = 0.5 and at one other time.

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The graph of h has a height of 20 at t = 0.5 and also at t = 2.5 seconds.

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: The height of a ball tossed straight upward from the ground can be modeled using a position function.
A position function can be visualized using a table, a graph, or algebraically with a formula.

Text.p: Velocity is a measure of how fast an object is moving and in which direction. Velocity can vary over time. Ex: The velocity of a tossed ball varies over the time between the initial toss of the ball and the ball coming to rest. Velocity can be positive, negative, or zero. The velocity of a thrown ball is positive on the way up, zero at the ball’s peak, and negative on the way down.

Average velocity is the change in an object’s position divided by the length of the time interval. In this lesson, we will calculate and interpret a tossed ball’s average velocity over different time intervals.

MultipleChoice.question: On which time interval did the ball’s height change by the greatest amount?

choice.label: Between t = 3 and t = 4
choice.explanation: The length of the time interval between t = 3 and t = 4 is 1 second. The position changed from 240 \text{ ft} to 256 \text{ ft}. So the position changed by 256 \text{ ft} - 240 \text{ ft} = 16 \text{ ft} in 1 second. This change in position is the least among the time intervals.

choice.label: Between t = 2 and t = 3
choice.explanation: The length of the time interval between t = 2 and t = 3 is 1 second. The position changed from 192 \text{ ft} to 240 \text{ ft}. So the position changed by 240 \text{ ft} - 192 \text{ ft} = 48 \text{ ft} in 1 second. This change in position is not the greatest among the time intervals.

choice.label: Between t = 1 and t = 2
choice.explanation: The length of the time interval between t = 1 and t = 2 is 1 second. The position changed from 112 \text{ ft} to 192 \text{ ft}. So the position changed by 192 \text{ ft} - 112 \text{ ft} = 80 \text{ ft} in 1 second. This change in position is the greatest among the time intervals.

ShortAnswer.question: What is the average velocity on the interval [1,4] \text{?}

hint.m: v_{ave} = \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}}

Hints.hint: The change in position is the difference in heights between t = 1 and t = 4 \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The average velocity is given by v_{ave} = \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}} \text{.}

TextResource.Text: s(t) represents the height of a ball in the air in feet t seconds after the ball is thrown.

ShortAnswer.question: If s(2) = 106 feet and s(5) = 10 feet, the change in position is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

Hints.hint: The change in position is s(5) - s(2) \text{.}

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The change in position is s(5) - s(2) = 10-106 = -96 feet.

ShortAnswer.question: If s(2) = 106 feet and s(5) = 10​​​​ feet, the length of the time interval is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} seconds.

Hints.hint: The length of the time interval is the difference between the two inputs.

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The length of the time interval is the difference between the two inputs: 5 - 2 = 3 seconds.

hint.m: \text{Average velocity} = \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}}

Hints.hint: Substitute -96 for the change in position and 3 for the length of time interval in the formula for average velocity.

MultipleChoice.question: The average velocity from t=2 to t = 5 seconds is negative because \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.label: the ball’s height is decreasing from t=2 to t = 5 seconds
choice.explanation: The average velocity does not incorporate what happens between t=2 and t=5 seconds. Rather, the average velocity only uses information about the ball at t=2 and t = 5 \text{.} In between those times the ball could be going up and then down.

choice.label: the ball is higher at t=5 seconds than at t = 2 seconds
choice.explanation: If the ball were higher at t=5 seconds than at t =2 seconds, then s(5)-s(2) would be positive. Since the length of the time interval is positive, the average velocity would also be positive.

choice.label: the ball is lower at t=5 seconds than at t = 2 seconds
choice.explanation: The change in position is negative, which can only happen when s(5) is smaller than s(2) \text{.} If the change in position is negative, the average velocity will also be negative.

hint.m: \text{Average velocity} = \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}}

Hints.hint: We know the change in position. Determine the length of the time interval.

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: Because the length of the time interval [1,3] is 2 , we can find the average velocity. \begin{align*} \text{Average velocity} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}} \\ &= \dfrac{32}{2} && \text{Substitute} \\ &= 16 \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \\ \end{align*}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: Velocity measures how fast an object is moving and in which direction.

Activity.title: Average velocity and the secant line

Text.p: This lesson introduces a way to visualize the ball’s average velocity using a line passing through two points on the graph of s(t) called a secant line. A secant line is a line that passes through any two points of a function. The slope of a secant line m_{sec} passing through a position function s(t) can be interpreted as the average velocity. Consequently, over a time interval [a,b]\text{:} v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(b) - s(a)}{b - a}

In the context of the ball’s motion, the steeper the secant line’s slope, the faster the ball is moving. A secant line that is increasing corresponds to a positive average velocity on that interval. A secant line that is decreasing corresponds to a negative average velocity on that interval.

ArcResource.title: Average velocity and the secant line

MultipleChoice.question: Which expression represents \text{rise}, or the change in position?

choice.explanation: The expression b - a represents \text{run}, the length of the time interval, not the change in position.
This expression reverses the order in which the positions at each time are subtracted. The change in position should be the final position minus the initial position.

ShortAnswer.question: What is the average velocity of the ball on the interval [1,5]? Recall that s(t) = -16t^2 + 128t \text{.}

Hints.hint: Use the formula v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(b) - s(a)}{b-a} \text{.}
On the interval [1,5], v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(5) - s(1)}{5 - 1} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: Use the formula v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(b) - s(a)}{b-a} given an interval [a,b] \text{.} Note that:
Substituting these values into the formula for v_{ave}, we get:

TextResource.Text: The term s(t) represents the height of the ball in feet t seconds after the ball is thrown.

MultipleChoice.question: The average velocity on the time interval [a,b] will be negative when \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.explanation: If s(a) > s(b) \text{,} then the change in position s(b) - s(a) will be negative. So the average velocity will also be negative.

If s(a) < s(b) \text{,} then the average velocity will be positive, not negative. The expression s(a) < s(b) means the change in position s(b) - s(a) will be positive, so the average velocity must also be positive.

If s(a) = s(b) \text{,} then the change in average velocity would be zero, not negative. If s(a) = s(b) \text{,} then the change in position is s(b)-s(a) = 0. Because this change in position is the numerator of the average velocity, the average velocity will also be zero.

MultipleChoice.question: If the average velocity of the ball on the time interval [a,b] is zero, the ball will \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.label: be on the ground at t=a and t=b
choice.explanation: While the average velocity in this situation would be zero, the average velocity is also zero at other time intervals. Consider what must be true of the numerator of the average velocity if the average velocity is zero.

choice.label: have maximum height at both t=a and t=b
choice.explanation: The ball only has one maximum height. So if both t=a and t=b correspond to the maximum height, then a = b \text{.} So the length of the time interval is zero. The length of the time interval is the denominator of the average velocity fraction, so the average velocity would not be defined on this time interval.

choice.label: have the same height at t=a and t=b
choice.explanation: If these heights are the same, then s(a) = s(b) and the change in position is s(b)-s(a) = 0 \text{.} So the average velocity is also zero.

question.p: The graph of s(t) is provided, along with points (a,s(a)) and (b,s(b)) \text{.}

image.description: Function <m>s(t)</m> on a coordinate plane, showing points <m>(a, s(a))</m> and <m>(b, s(b))</m> for average velocity via secant line.

question.p: The average velocity of the ball from t=a to t=b is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.label: negative
choice.explanation: If the average velocity were negative, then the change in position would also have to be negative. Consider whether this change in position is positive, negative, or zero.

choice.label: positive
choice.explanation: s(b) is greater than s(a) \text{,} so the change in position will be positive. The average velocity will also be positive.

choice.label: zero
choice.explanation: If the average velocity were zero, then the heights of the ball would need to be the same at the two times: s(a) = s(b) \text{,} which is not the case.

TextResource.Text: The graph of the height of a ball s(t) in feet t seconds after the ball is thrown is provided, along with several points on the graph: 5, 115)</m>, <m>(3, 111)</m>, <m>(4, 79)</m>, <m>(5, 15)</m>; function increases then decreases.

MultipleChoice.question: The average velocity is greatest on the interval \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.explanation:
The secant line on [0,1] is steeper than the secant lines on [0,2] and [0,2.5] \text{.}
5,115)</m>, <m>(3,111)</m>, <m>(4,79)</m>, <m>(5,15)</m>; secant lines from <m>(0,15)</m> to others show average velocity.

The secant line on the interval [0,2] is not the steepest secant line. Another interval has a steeper secant line. Draw the secant lines to identify which rises most quickly. A steeper secant line corresponds to a greater average velocity.

While the slope of the secant line on [0,2.5] is positive, that slope is not the largest. Draw the two other secant lines to identify which is steepest. A steeper secant line corresponds to a greater average velocity.

MultipleChoice.question: The average velocity will be zero on the interval \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.explanation: The slope of the secant line on [1,2.5] is positive, and therefore not zero. So the average velocity is not zero. Function <m>s(t)</m> with labeled points, showing a secant line between <m>(1, 79)</m> and <m>(3, 111)</m> on a coordinate plane.

The slope of the secant line on [1,3] is positive, and therefore not zero. So the average velocity is not zero. Function <m>s(t)</m> on a coordinate plane with a secant line connecting points <m>(1, 79)</m> and <m>(3, 111)</m>; labeled critical point at <m>(2.

Because s(1) = s(4) \text{,} the change in position will be zero, so the velocity will be zero. We can also notice that the secant line is horizontal, indicating a slope of zero. 5, 115)</m>, labeled points at <m>(0, 15)</m>, <m>(1, 79)</m>, <m>(2, 111)</m>, <m>(3, 111)</m>, <m>(4, 79)</m>, <m>(5, 15)</m>, and a secant line from <m>(1, 79)</m> to <m>(4, 79)</m> on a coordinate plane.

The slope of the secant line on [2,5] is negative, and therefore not zero. So the average velocity is not zero. 5, 115)</m> and <m>(5, 15)</m>; the secant line between these points shows average velocity.

question.p: The change in position of the ball from t=1 to t=5 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

Hints.hint: The change in position is s(5) - s(1) \text{.}

ShortAnswer.question: The length of the time interval from t=1 to t=5 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} seconds.

Hints.hint: Subtract the smaller time from the larger time.

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The length of the time interval is the larger time minus the smaller time: 5-1 = 4 seconds.

question.p: The average velocity from t=1 to t=5 is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \text{.}

hint.m: v_{\text{ave}} = \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}}

CorrectExplanation.me: \begin{align*} s(t) &= -16t^2 + 128t\\ s(1) &= -16(1)^2 + 128(1) \\ &= 112 \\ s(5) &= -16(5)^2 + 128(5) \\ &= 240 \\ v_{\text{ave}} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}}\\ &= \dfrac{240 - 112}{5-1}\\ &= \dfrac{128}{4} \\ &= 32 \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}}\\ \end{align*}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: A secant line is a line that passes through any two points of a function.
The steepness of the secant line’s slope gives information about how fast an object is moving. The steeper the slope, the greater the average velocity is on that interval.

Activity.title: Instantaneous velocity and the tangent line

Text.p: In previous lessons we talked about how to find the average velocity. But sometimes we’d like to find the velocity at a specific time instead over of a time interval. An object’s instantaneous velocity determines how fast the object is moving at time t = a \text{.}

In this lesson, we will examine the average velocity on the interval [a,t] for different values of t that are close to a \text{.} We end by providing a more formal definition of instantaneous velocity and the graphical representation of instantaneous velocity as the slope of a tangent line.

ArcResource.title: Instantaneous velocity and the tangent line

ShortAnswer.question: What is the average velocity of the ball on the interval [1,3]? Recall that s(t) = -16t^2 + 128t \text{.}

Hints.hint: Use the formula v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(b) - s(a)}{b-a} \text{.}
On the interval [1,3] \text{,} v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(3) - s(1)}{3 - 1} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: Use the formula v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(b) - s(a)}{b-a} given an interval [a,b] \text{.} Note that:
Substituting these values into the formula for v_{ave}, we get:

ShortAnswer.question: What value does v_{ave} approach as t becomes closer to 1 ?

Hints.hint: Try finding the average velocity for [1,1.00001] \text{.}
Try finding the average velocity for [1,1.000001] \text{.}

ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: As time approaches closer and closer to t = 1 from the right on the number line, the value of \dfrac{s(t) - s(1)}{t-1} approaches 96 \dfrac{\text{ft}}{\text{s}} \text{.} We can do a similar analysis using values to the left of t = 1 \text{,} such as 0.99, 0.999, and so on.

choice.label: the slope of the secant line on the interval [1.99,2]
choice.explanation: The slope of this secant line on the interval [1.99,2]​​​​​ is the average velocity, not the instantaneous velocity. To get the instantaneous velocity, we must determine what happens to the average velocities as the interval gets even smaller.

choice.label: the slope of the secant line on the interval [2,2.01]
choice.explanation: The slope of this secant line on the interval [2,2.01]​​​​ is the average velocity, not the instantaneous velocity. To get the instantaneous velocity, we must determine what happens to the average velocities as the interval gets even smaller.

choice.label: the slope of the tangent line at t=2
choice.explanation: The instantaneous velocity is found by finding average velocities over smaller intervals. These average velocities are slopes of secant lines that approach the slope of the tangent line.

choice.label: the velocity the instant the ball is thrown

TextResource.Text: The function s(t) = -16t^2 +96t represents the height in feet of a ball t seconds after the ball is thrown. Find the instantaneous velocity of the ball at t=2 seconds.

MultipleChoice.question: A good strategy for finding the instantaneous velocity at t=2 is to compute \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

choice.explanation: This option represents only a single average velocity, not the instantaneous velocity. Several average velocities need to be computed to find the instantaneous velocity.

choice.label: the average velocities on intervals [t,2] and [2,t] as t gets closer to 2
the average velocity from t = 0 to t = 2
choice.explanation: This option will only yield an average velocity, not the instantaneous velocity. The instantaneous velocity is found by computing several average velocities over shrinking intervals.

choice.label: the height s(t) of the ball as t gets closer to 2
choice.explanation: This option only considers the heights and not the average velocities of the ball. The instantaneous velocity is computed by finding several average velocities over shrinking intervals.

question.p: To find the instantaneous velocity of the ball at t=2 \text{,} find the average velocities over intervals [t,2] and [2,t] as t gets closer to 2 \text{.} To that end, the average velocity on [2,2.1] is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}}. Enter your answer as ##.#.
Similarly, the average velocity on [1.9,2] is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}}. Enter your answer as ##.#.
We have found two helpful average velocities. The following table includes these two average velocities and four others over smaller time intervals.
Using this table, the instantaneous velocity of the ball at t=2 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \text{.}

Hints.hint: Find the number the average velocities are approaching as the intervals shrink in size and the endpoints get closer to 2 \text{.}

Text.p: Lesson summary

list.item: An object’s instantaneous velocity determines how fast the object is moving at time t=a \text{.}

Text.p: A table of values for the linear function f(x) is given.

question.p: The rate of change of f is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The rate of change is the slope of the function.
Using the points (1, 3) and (2, 1) gives:

question.p: The algebraic representation of the linear function is f(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The linear function can be written as f(x) = mx + b \text{.}
So f(x) = mx + b = -2x + 5 \text{.}

Text.p: The graph of the linear function f(x) :

image.description: Linear function <m>f(x)</m> on an <m>xy</m>-plane, decreasing, y-intercept at <m>(0, 1)</m>, no critical points or asymptotes.f(x) = -\dfrac{1}{3} x + 1 .

question.p: The rate of change of f is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The rate of change is the slope of the graph. The graph goes through (0, 1) and (3, 0) \text{.}
Using these two points gives the slope:

question.p: The algebraic representation for the linear function is f(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.p: The linear function can be written as f(x) = mx + b \text{.}
So f(x) = mx + b = -\dfrac{1}{3} x + 1 \text{.}

Text.p: The height of a ball thrown into the air is modeled by s(t) = -16t^2 + 80t + 10 \text{,} where s is given in feet and t is given in seconds after the ball is thrown.

image.description: Function <m>s(t) = -16t^2 + 80t + 10</m> on <m>(t, s)</m> axes, showing a maximum at the critical point <m>(2.5, 110)f(x) = -16x^2 + 80x + 10 .

question.p: The height of the ball the instant the ball is thrown is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

CorrectExplanation.p: The ball is thrown at t = 0 seconds. So the height the instant the ball is thrown is s(0) = -16(0)^2 + 80(0) + 10 = 10 feet.

question.p: The maximum height of the ball is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

CorrectExplanation.p: The maximum of the graph is (2.5, 110) \text{.} The maximum height is the second coordinate: 110\text{ feet.}

question.p: The maximum height of the ball is achieved at \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} seconds.

CorrectExplanation.p: The highest point on the graph is (2.5, 110) \text{.} The first coordinate is the time the maximum height is achieved: 2.5 \text{ seconds.}

question.p: The height of the ball 1 second after the ball is thrown is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} feet.

CorrectExplanation.p: The height of the ball after 1 second is s(1) = -16(1)^2 + 80(1) + 10 = 74 \text{.}

question.p: The ball will be at the same height at t = 1 second and t = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} seconds.

CorrectExplanation.p: The graph of h has the same height at t = 1 as the graph has at t = 4 \text{.}

image.description: (2.5, 110)</m>; <m>s(1) = s(4)</m>; concave down between <m>t = 0</m> and <m>t = 5</m>.f(x) = -16x^2 + 80x + 10 . Dashed line at y = 74 .

Text.p: A table of values of the height s(t) of a ball t seconds after the ball is thrown:

question.p: The average velocity of the ball from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{seconds}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.me: \begin{align*} s(0) &= 15 \\ s(3) &= 111 \\ \text{Average velocity} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}} \\ &= \dfrac{s(3) - s(0)}{3 - 0} \\ &= \dfrac{111 - 15}{3} \\ &= \dfrac{96}{3} \\ &= 32 \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \\ \end{align*}

question.p: The average velocity of the ball from t = 3 to t = 5 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{seconds}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.me: \begin{align*} s(3) &= 111 \\ s(5) &= 15 \\ \text{Average velocity} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}} \\ &= \dfrac{s(5) - s(3)}{5 - 3} \\ &= \dfrac{15 - 111}{2} \\ &= \dfrac{-96}{2} \\ &= -48 \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \\ \end{align*}

question.p: The average velocity of the ball from t = 1 to t = 4 seconds is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{seconds}} \text{.}

CorrectExplanation.me: \begin{align*} s(1) &= 79 \\ s(4) &= 79 \\ \text{Average velocity} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in position}}{\text{Length of time interval}} \\ &= \dfrac{s(4) - s(1)}{4 - 1} \\ &= \dfrac{79 - 79}{3} \\ &= \dfrac{0}{3} \\ &= 0\\ \end{align*}

Text.p: s(t) = -16t^2 + 96t + 15 represents the height in feet of a ball t seconds after the ball is thrown.

question.p: The average velocity of the ball from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \text{.}
The average velocity of the ball from t = 2 to t = 5 seconds is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \text{.}
The average velocity of the ball from t = 1 to t = 5 seconds is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{second}} \text{.}

Text.p: When using meters instead of feet, the equation for the height of a ball is slightly different.
The equation s(t) = -4.9t^2 + 20t represents the height of the ball in meters t seconds after the ball is thrown.
Find the instantaneous velocity of the ball at t = 2.5 seconds.

question.p: The average velocity of the ball on the interval [2.49,2.5] is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{meters}}{\text{second}} \text{.}
Enter your answer as #.###.
The average velocity of the ball on the interval [2.5,2.51] is v_{\text{ave}} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \, \dfrac{\text{meters}}{\text{second}} \text{.}
Enter your answer as #.###.
The following table includes the two average velocities found earlier in addition to four other average velocities over smaller time intervals.
